awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An Examination of Household Risk Assessment Judgments and Protective Action Decision during Tornado Threats
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will improve understanding of the kinds of information people seek when facing a tornado threat, how the information they obtain affects their risk perceptions, and the way that their risk perceptions affect their protective actions. This project will have a number of positive impacts to the broader society. Experimental materials (including software) will be made publicly available to a range of researchers, including those from under-represented groups, so that other studies may augment and extend the approach developed here. The project also includes extensive outreach to professional broadcast meteorologists and to organizations such as the National Weather Service, Federal Emergency Management Agency, and state and local government emergency management agencies in order to inform how weather-related risks are communicated to the public. 

This project will introduce two major innovations into research on protective action decision making (here, in the context of tornado-related risk). First, in a departure from conventional, exclusively survey-based studies, human-in-the-loop experiments incorporating computer-based dynamic decision making exercises will be used. Alternative protective actions (such as seeking additional information, shelter in-place, or evacuating) will be investigated by examining detailed logs of participant interaction with the computer-based simulation. Second, this project will overcome a limitation of previous studies that have focused solely on individuals by comparing decision processes by individual with those of pairs (here, married couples). This work is therefore expected to reveal how interpersonal ties help determine protective actions in households.

por.por_cntn:
This project improves our understanding of the kinds of information people seek when facing a tornado threat, how the information they obtain affects their risk perceptions, and the way that their risk perceptions affect their protective actions. The project’s findings are likely to impact local communities, policymakers, and emergency managers, enabling them to better communicate tornado risks across the country.

Intellectual merit: The project provides valuable insights into individual and household decision-making processes prior to taking protective actions, using tornado threat scenarios. Our investigation revealed that participants in the study show a preference for textual information that provides written information. This includes details like recommendations for protective actions, potential impacts, hazards, and the location of the storm. This preference was observed particularly during rare tornado threats, indicating a distinct preference for textual information over tornado risk maps. Furthermore, the study highlighted that social contexts play a significant role in influencing how people seek information. Specifically, couples demonstrated a greater investment of time in reviewing information compared to individual males and females. Understanding these dynamics sheds light on the factors that shape information-seeking behaviors within households, especially in regions with a low risk of tornadoes.

Broader Impacts: The implications of these findings extend to providing valuable guidance for authorities and meteorologists in refining risk communication strategies. Recognizing the preference for clear textual information during rare tornado threats and considering the influence of social dynamics, including group decision-making, allows for more effective and targeted communication efforts. This knowledge can contribute to enhancing overall preparedness and response strategies in low-risk regions, ultimately improving the effectiveness of public communication during tornado threats. Furthermore,  project data and the source code for DynaSearch is currently accessible upon request and will be deposited in an open-source data repository, DesignSafe-CI, within a year after the project concludes. The project findings have been submitted to three major peer-reviewed journals in the field of risk research. In addition, our research team delivered six conference presentations during the grant period. The materials used for data collection are employed in all the investigators' universities for a range of courses, including Research Methods, Risk Analysis, Disaster Response, etc. Additionally, the project has supported minority and female students pursuing their Masters and Ph.D. degrees.

Modified by: Shih-Kai Huang
